Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical study and finite element simulation of wave propagation in metamaterials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since 2000, the study of metamaterials has attracted the attention of many scientists and engineers. Wave propagation in metamaterials is of interest in various disciplines and could potentially revolutionize design of efficient antennas, waveguides and radars, nanolithography and subwavelength imaging, near field control and manipulation (useful for detecting low levels of chemical and biological agents, and manipulation of molecules), particle detection, and invisibility cloaking (useful for stealth technology). Developing robust and efficient algorithms for modeling metamaterials will benefit diverse areas such as electrical engineering, materials science, optics, physics, nano-technology, and biomedical technology.

The goal of this project is to study problems of wave interaction with metamaterials through mathematical modeling and computer simulations. Mathematical modeling plays an important role in the design and application of metamaterials. In October 2006 using computer simulations, a group of researchers at Duke University found a way to fabricate the metamaterials to build a 2-D "invisibility cloak" that makes an object invisible to certain frequencies. However, most metamaterial models proposed by engineers are not well studied and there is a lack of solid mathematical analysis and modeling. Metamaterials are lossy and dispersive, which leads to governing equations which are much more complicated than the well-studied Maxwell?s equations in free space. Approximating solutions of the metamaterial equations accurately and efficiently is challenging (note that all unknowns are objects in three dimensional spaces and vary in time) and requires additional research. This project will develop mathematically robust, accurate, and efficient, finite element methods that can be be used for simulating wave interactions with metamaterials. During the proposed project the PI will train graduate students interested in pursuing careers in computational sciences and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since year 2000, the study of the artificially manufactured metamaterials with both negative permittivity and permeability has been a very hot research topic due to many interesting potential applications, such as design of efficient antenna, waveguide and radar, nanolithography and subwavelength imaging, near field control for detecting low levels of chemical and biological agents and manipulation of molecules, particle detection, and invisibility cloaks.

Because of the complexity of wave propagation happened in metamaterials
and the cost of physical experiments, computer simulation of wave propagation in metamaterials plays an important role in designing functional metamaterials and finding interesting applications of metamaterials.

Through the support of this NSF grant, the Principal Investigator (PI)
investigated many robust and efficient algorithms for simulating wave propagation in heterogeneous media involving metamaterials. Interesting mathematical modeling equations for simulating arbitrary star-shaped electromagnetic cloaks, optical black hole, and other transformation optic devices with metamaterials are developed and efficient time-domain finite element methods have been proposed and implemented. Over the four year funding period, the PI has published 25 research papers in top journals and delivered many lectures in universities and research conferences to disseminate the findings. The PI graduated one U.S. citizen Ph.D student in 2017, and now he works at Sandia National Laboratories as a Postdoctoral Scientist. Two more Ph.D students got partial support from this grant too and will graduate with their Ph.D degrees in 2019 and 2020, respectively.

The findings thought this project will improve our computational knowledge by further advancing the finite element theory and applications, which will
benefit broader areas such as electrical engineering, materials, optics,
physics, nano-technology, and biomedical technology.
